clinical_study.brief_title: An RCT of SHS Among Non-smoking Children
clinical_study.official_title: Reducing Exposure to Tobacco Smoke From Multiple Sources Among Never-smoking Children - a Cluster Randomised Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This is a school- and family-based prospective study in randomly selected clusters among Primary/Grade 3-4 (P3-4) students in all the 5 regions of Hong Kong, which aims at reducing children's exposure to secondhand and thirdhand smoke. This study includes a baseline screening survey (to identify eligible subjects), baseline assessments (including hair nicotine analysis and child-reported outcomes), interventions and 12-month follow-up assessments.

detailed_description.textblock:
The interventions consist of a 30-minute briefing, worksheets and mobile instant messages. Worksheets aiming at preventing students' tobacco exposure will be mailed weekly to the homes for them and parents to complete together in the first 12 weeks. About 4 mobile instant messages per week will be sent to students and parents in the first 12 weeks. Control students will receive minimal interventions to reduce tobacco exposure. The assessments in the follow-up 6 months and 12 months include hair nicotine analysis, student and parent survey. All questionnaire data, individual baseline and follow-up data (6-month and 12-month) will be matched and analysed.
Aims of this study: (1) to reduce exposure to tobacco smoke, secondhand smoke (SHS) and thirdhand smoke (THS) among children, (2) to reduce children's intention to smoke, (3) to reduce children's respiratory symptoms, (4) to promote avoidance of SHS among children, (5) to promote children's perception of family happiness, (6) to promote smoking cessation of the primary source of SHS exposure.

study_design_info.masking_description: All participants will be told that they will be randomly allocated to one of two interventions, and will be advised not to discuss with others parents and students about the intervention. The group status of hair samples will not be revealed to the Laboratory. Variables applicable only to the intervention arm (e.g. process evaluation items) will be kept in a separate data set, and the data analysts will be blinded to the group status of observations.

primary_outcome.measure: Objectively measured exposure to tobacco smoke among children.
primary_outcome.description: In the 6th month, students will be gathered in a classroom for hair collection separately for each group to reduce potential contamination subsequently. A small sample of 30-50 strands of hair will be cut at the back of head near the scalp by trained research staff. The hair sample will be clearly labelled and stored in a zip lock bag and sent to an overseas laboratory to analyse the nicotine content with a standard method. Hair grows at about 1cm per month, so the examination of 1-2cm of hair closest to the scalp will reflect exposure to tobacco smoke in the past 1-2 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Children's self-reported exposure to secondhand smoke and thirdhand smoke.
secondary_outcome.description: In the 6th and 12th months, children will report their exposure to secondhand smoke and thirdhand smoke by answering 3 questions in the questionnaire: 1) During the past 7 days, how many days did people smoke near you when you were at home? 2) During the past 7 days, how many days did you smell secondhand smoke from outside when you were at home? 3) During the past 7 days, if there was no one smoking, how many days did you smell tobacco when you were at home?

In the 6th and 12th months, children will report their avoidance of secondhand smoke by answering 2 questions in the questionnaire: 1) During the past 7 days, what did you do if anyone smoked in your home when you were at home? The options include opening windows, turning on exhaust fan, staying far away from smokers or smoking areas, asking smokers go to another place, asking smokers stop smoking, other actions and no actions. 2) If anyone smoked in your home when you were at home, whether would you ask them to stop smoking?

In the 6th and 12th months, children will report their intention to smoke by answering 2 questions in the questionnaire: 1) If one of your good friends ask you to smoke, whether would you accept? 2) Do you think you will smoke in the following 12 months?

In the 6th and 12th months, children will report their respiratory symptoms by answering 2 questions in the questionnaire: 1) On the whole, how do you think of your health status? The options include excellent (=5), very good (=4), satisfactory (=3), fair (=2) and poor (=1), with higher scores indicating better health status. 2) During the recent 30 days, did you often cough or have phlegm in your throat?

In the 6th and 12th months, children will report their perception of family happiness by answering 2 questions in the questionnaire: 1) During the recent 30 days, was there any unpleasantness in your family? 2) On the whole, how do you think of your family happiness? The options include very happy, happy, unhappy and very unhappy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Smoking cessation (past 7 days) of the primary source of secondhand smoke.
secondary_outcome.description: In the 6th and 12th months, non-smoking mothers will report the smoking cessation (past 7 days) of the primary smokers at home by answering 2 questions in the questionnaire: 1) During the past 7 days, how many cigarettes did the primary smoker use? 2) During the past 6 months, have the primary smoker ever tried to quit smoking?

arm_group.description: A briefing, 12 worksheets and 48 mobile instant messages or Whatsapp messages.
Control students will receive the following minimal intervention to reduce tobacco exposure. A shorter briefing, a leaflet on tobacco exposure published by the Department of Health.

intervention.description: A briefing will be given to students, while they take turns for hair collection at baseline. Research staff will introduce the intervention, explain hair collection procedure and discuss issues related to SHS with the aim to encourage participation and avoidance of SHS.

Worksheets will be mailed weekly to the homes for students and parents to complete together in the first 12 weeks. The worksheets' content will include 1) smoking prevalence (emphasising the low local prevalence and non-smoking norms), 2) harms of smoking and benefits of quitting, 3) harms of SHS, 4) the concept of THS, how it can be reduced (e.g. not to smoke at home even in the absence of children), and its potential carcinogenic effect, 4) benefits of avoidance behaviours to SHS, 5) harms of SHS from neighbours and measures to reduce such exposure (e.g. closing windows; complaining to property management office), 6) local resources for cessation (e.g. quitline and smoking cessation clinics), etc.

intervention.intervention_name: Mobile instant messages or Whatsapp messages
intervention.description: To reinforce intervention messages especially among adult household members and smokers, mobile instant messages will be used. The children will also receive these messages if they use smartphones. WhatsApp is widely used in Hong Kong. For the expected small number of smokers who do not use smartphones, SMS will be used.
A leaflet on tobacco exposure published by the Department of Health will be mailed to the control group.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Never smoked P3-4 primary school students.
- Exposed to SHS at home from smokers inside home in any of the past 7 days.
- Living with at least 1 smoker.
- Living with a non-smoking mother.
Mothers of initially eligible students will receive an invitation letter and verify the above eligibility criteria plus the following additional criteria:
- No plan to change school or move away from Hong Kong in the next 15 months.
- No physical or mental illness that may prevent the child from taking part in the study (e.g. illness that require foreseeable hospitalisation).
- Agree for a sample of the child's hair to be collected at baseline, 6-month.
- The child's hair is and will be at least 3cm long in the next 7 months.
- No chemical treatment (e.g. colouring) to child's hair in the past 6 months and the next 7 months.
- If more than 1 child is invited, only the younger child is eligible.
- The mother uses a mobile phone.
Exclusion Criteria:
- special school and international school students.
